Package net.proteusframework.core.mail

The com.i2rd.java.mail package provides classes that let the developer generate and send mail messages easily.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    EmailAddressProvider
    Implementors provide email addresses.
    MailDataHandler
    A DataHandler specific to mail messages.
    MailPart
    Defines the data that encapsulates a part of an email message such as a body part or an attachment part.
    MessageFilter
    MessageFilter provides implementers the possibility of transforming, filtering, and adding to a message as it is built.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AbstractMailPart
    Abstract implementation of mail part.
    EmailAddress
    Recipient / Address container for unparsed InternetAddresses.
    EmailAddressValidator
    Validates an email address.
    EmailValidationResult
    Container for the result of an email validation test.
    FileMailPart
    MailPart backed by a java.io.File.
    MailMessage
    This class can be used to generate a multipart MIME message.
    MailMessageBeanInfo
    MailMessage BeanInfo.
    MailMessageSource
    A generic DataSource implementation for use with the MailMessage utility class.
    MemoryMailPart
    MailPart backed stored in memory.
    MessageFilterAdapter
    Adapter for MessageFilter.
    TransportAgent
    A TransportAgent manages a Transport.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    EmailValidationResult.Outcome
    Outcome.
    EmailValidationType
    Type of email validation.
    MailMessage.DestinationType
    RFC 2822 destination address type.
    MailMessage.OriginatorType
    RFC 2822 originator address type.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    MailDataHandlerException
    A wrapper for exceptions caught while accessing data in a MailDataHandler.

Package net.proteusframework.core.mail Description

The com.i2rd.java.mail package provides classes that let the developer generate and send mail messages easily.

There are 3 main components in the mail module: a utility for creating email messages, an email address validator, and a utility for sending messages.

The most commonly used component is the utility for creating email messages. Usage examples follow. For more information regarding usage, see the README file.

Simple messages: 

 // Creates a simple plain text message
 MailMessage mm = new MailMessage();
 // The from field and subject are always required.
 // At least one recipient must be specified.
 mm.setFrom("noone@email.com");
 mm.addTo("noone@email.com");
 mm.setSubject("Plain text message");
 // You must always specify the character set.
 mm.setBody("Plain text content.", "US-ASCII", "text/plain");
 mm.getMessage(); // equivalent to mm.getMessage(true)

 // Creates a simple html text message
 MailMessage mm = new MailMessage();
 mm.setFrom("noone@email.com");
 mm.addTo("noone@email.com");
 mm.setSubject("Html text message");
 mm.setBody("<html><body bgcolor=\"#bbbbbb\">"
 + "<b>Html text message</b></body></html>",
 "US-ASCII", "text/html"); // Notice the content type is different.
 mm.getMessage();

Messages with attachments: 

 // File attachment
 MailMessage mm = new MailMessage();
 mm.setFrom("noone@email.com");
 mm.addTo("noone@email.com");
 mm.setSubject("Plain text message");
 mm.setBody("Plain text content.", "US-ASCII", "text/plain");
 File someFile = new File("/tmp/someFile.txt");
 // If the disposition is not set, the disposition defaults to "attachment"
 // and the filename, size, and last modified time are included in the
 // email message.
 // The content type is automatically gleaned from the file extension
 mm.addAttachment(someFile, "Description of the file.", null );
 mm.getMessage();

 // Input stream attachment.
 MailMessage mm = new MailMessage();
 mm.setFrom("noone@email.com");
 mm.addTo("noone@email.com");
 mm.setSubject("Plain text message");
 mm.setBody("Plain text content.", "US-ASCII", "text/plain");
 InputStream is = ResultSet.getBinaryStream(1); // Imaginary result set.
 String fileName = ResultSet.getString(2); // Imaginary result set.
 MailMessageSource mms = new MailMessageSource(is, "audio/x-wav", fileName);
 mm.addAttachment(mms);
 mm.getMessage();

 // Another way to accomplish the same thing
 MailMessage mm = new MailMessage();
 mm.setFrom("noone@email.com");
 mm.addTo("noone@email.com");
 mm.setSubject("Plain text message");
 mm.setBody("Plain text content.", "US-ASCII", "text/plain");
 InputStream is = ResultSet.getBinaryStream(1); // Imaginary result set.
 String fileName = ResultSet.getString(2); // Imaginary result set.
 mm.addAttachment(is, "An instructional audio file.", "audio/x-wav",
 "attachment; filename=" + fileName);
 mm.getMessage();

Multiple representations of the same content. 

 String plainContent = "Test Message.";
 String htmlContent = "<html><body>"
 + "<font size=\"+1\" color=\"red\">Test Message.</font>"
 + "</body></html>";

 MailMessage mm = new MailMessage();
 mm.setFrom("noone@email.com");
 mm.addTo("noone@email.com");
 mm.setSubject("Alternate message");
 // TIP: string content defaults to "text/plain" if you use this method.
 mm.addBody(plainContent, "UTF-8");
 mm.addBody(htmlContent, "UTF-8", "text/html");
 mm.getMessage();
Depending on the mail clients capabilities and preferences, it could either display the plain version or the html version.

As an example, you could use this functionality to send email content as plain text, an rtf document, and as a word document. Since not everyone has word installed, some mail clients may display the rtf document instead. Still others may display the plain text document. Body content should be added to the message in the order of increasing faithfulness to the original content.
